title: Meta: request Apology to the Courts following the Lowcock report into the Street Trees Dispute

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
Paul Brooke submitted an FOI: “Apology to the Courts following the Lowcock report into the Street Trees Dispute”
In the councils public apology posted here:
https://www.sheffield.gov.uk/sites/defau...
“It was not only the public who were misled. While the Inquiry found that the outcomes of legal action would have been the same without the Council's version of the 5-year tree management strategy, this document was misleading and mishandled. The Council should have removed it from circulation and made the Courts aware that it was not part of Amey's operational approach. Misleading the Courts is a serious matter and we will write to them to apologise.”
I’ve have been waiting for a response for Paul Brook FOI, as I have been interested in this apology. Paul’s FOI is past its statutory response time. And I would like to understand why.
—-
This requestor is seeking to understand what searches for records were undertaken when responding to this request, and how the council requested recorded information from record custodians. In addition to, how the council handled this request.
Recorded information relevant to this request will include, but not be limited to: communication from the FOI team to the relevant parties who held requested information and records sought. The responses in-turn received.   Any discussion how to respond to this request.
Yours faithfully,
Mc

Our delay in replying to Paul Brooke’s request for information about the
council’s apology to the court has been because this document had not been
drafted.
We have delayed our response until the apology is made. We are expecting
that the apology will be issued to the court this week, and that it will
be published by the council in due course.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.

Dear FOI,
Not to be a pain about this. But. Surely then if the information has not been drafted then your response to Paul Brooke could have been as follows, within the statutory time frame of his request from 27th September.
####
1. Has an apology been issued to the Courts and if so, the date(s) and address(es) to which it(they) was sent.
No.
####
2. The text of any such apology made or a copy of the apology or apologies to the Courts.
Information not held.
#####
5. Have any replies or responses been received from the Courts?
Information not held.
#####
6. Copies or text of any replies received from the Courts.
information not held
#####
I don’t see why FOI requests are been delayed because the council is dragging its feet issuing this apology.
Yours sincerely,
Marcus Combie

Dear FOI,
Now the apology has been published. Any chance of a response on this one?
Yours sincerely,
Marcus Combie

Dear FOI,
But you did have records, you had records of which you reached out the information holders, asking I imagine do you have this apology, and they replied back stating they didn’t have it. That’s a record.
This is going to need an internal review, you didn’t provide any recorded information in relation to the handling of this request.
Just because you didn’t have the apology, doesn’t mean there were no records created where the FOI team ascertained they didn’t hold the information requested by Paul.
“This requestor is seeking to understand what searches for records were undertaken when responding to this request, and how the council requested recorded information from record custodians. In addition to, how the council handled this request.
Recorded information relevant to this request will include, but not be limited to: communication from the FOI team to the relevant parties who held requested information and records sought. The responses in-turn received.   Any discussion how to respond to this request.“
And considering the council made various responses to Paul stating:
“ Thank you for your request for information relating to Apology to court which we received on 27/09/2023.
We apologise for not meeting our deadline set out in our email of
29/09/2023. We will contact you with a further update on 30/10/23. We apologise for any inconvenience.”
“ We apologise for the delay in providing your response. We are actively working on your request. We will provide you a date by which you can expect your response as soon as we can.”
“ Thank you for your email of 1 December 2023 giving us a deadline of 6 December 2023. Please grant us another 24 hours to make a reply to you.”
“ Thank you for your recent request for an internal review relating to
apology to court which we received on 25/01/2024. We are sorry to hear
that you are not happy with your response.”
Yours sincerely,
Marcus Combie

Dear Marcus Combie,
Thank you for your recent request for an internal review relating to
apology to the courts which we received on 09/03/2024. We are sorry to
hear that you are not happy with your response.
This has now been logged and will be carried out by a member of the team.
The Freedom of Information Code of Practice states that we should aim to
your request for internal review within 20 working days, by 10/04/2024.
Please do not hesitate to contact us at the email address below if you
have any queries.
Please note that the Code of Practice does allow us to extend this
deadline by an additional 20 days in some situations. If we need more time
to complete the internal review, we will contact you to inform you of
this.
If you have any queries in the meantime, please contact us at the email
address below.
Yours sincerely,
